awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Investigating the Impact of Temporal and Spatial Variations on Lava Emplacement Through Numerical and Physical Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Effusive volcanic eruptions, such as those observed in Hawaii, are the primary mechanism for emplacing magma at the surface of terrestrial planets and moons to create new land. Lava flows and domes hold key information about planetary evolution. On Earth, the products of effusive eruptions - lava flows and domes - present a serious natural hazard to nearby populations. Thus, understanding what controls lava emplacement is crucial to mitigation of those hazards not only for humans but also to livestock and crops. This CAREER project aims to improve scientific understanding of effusive volcanic eruptions, that is, eruptions that produce lava flows and domes. Specifically, the project examines and quantifies the influence of temporal in lava effusion, and spatial variations in the environment onto which the lava is emplaced, on flow emplacement and stability. The project uses a combination of new numerical models and fluid mechanics experiments. The project team includes an early-career female principal investigator, a graduate student, and high-school students and teachers from underrepresented groups in the geosciences. 

Field data from recent eruptions, made possible by advances in observations techniques, have challenged existing models of lava emplacement. Observations suggest an important influence of temporal variations in lava effusion and of spatial variations in pre-existing environment on the evolution and final structure of lava flows and the stability of domes. The main tools this project will employ are numerical models and fluid mechanics experiments using liquids analogous to natural lavas. The numerical models will be designed to accommodate temporal and spatial variability in lava emplacement. The codes will be open-source and benchmarked, so that others in the community can use them further. Fluid mechanics experiments will use both analog materials such as syrup and wax, and molten natural basalts. Careful rheological analysis will accompany the experiments and be used to inform the numerical models, and scaling analysis will ensure transferability of the results to natural systems. The results of this project are likely to improve the assessment and mitigation of volcanic hazards through and enhanced understanding of the processes that control lava emplacement. The public appeal of volcanology will be harnessed to promote Earth Science literacy, scientific careers and college preparedness for high-school students, particularly at underserved and underrepresented communities. This project involves an international collaboration with scientists in Europe and strengthens collaboration between university scientists and the United States Geological Survey (USGS).

por.por_cntn:
Effusive volcanic eruptions are the primary way magma reaches the surface of planets and moons. The resulting lava flows and domes provide crucial insights into planetary evolution. On Earth, these lava flows and domes pose significant natural hazards, making it essential to understand what controls their emplacement. This project explored how changes in lava effusion over time and variations in the environment affect the evolution and structure of lava flows and domes. A variety of techniques were used, including numerical models, computer simulations, laboratory experiments with lava analogs like wax and syrup, and fieldwork involving the collection of lava samples and videos.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

Laboratory experiments using lava analogs allowed us to quantify how the roughness of the ground impacts the speed of lava flow. For instance, how much faster flows move on smoother terrains compared to rougher ones. This finding helps improve the accuracy of lava flow predictions, aiding in hazard forecasting and mitigation during eruptions. Experiments with solidifying wax demonstrated that lava flow widths quickly adjust to changes in ground slope, validating models that focus on local conditions rather than the entire flow history. Another set of experiments, using a programmable pump, showed that variations in effusion rates affect the structure and stability of lava domes, influencing their potential for collapse and hazard. Postdoctoral researcher Dr. Elise Rumpf led much of this work, alongside undergraduate students and high school interns. Dr. Rumpf is now a volcanologist with the US Geological Survey.

Three new numerical models of lava flows were developed through the project. Postdoctoral researcher Dr. Colton Conroy created the first model to simulate lava flow within complex channel geometries (e.g., branched channel networks), improving predictions for flow speed and thickness. Graduate student Janine Birnbaum developed a second model to simultanously simulate both the liquid and solidified parts of lava flows, a challenging task that enhances our understanding of flow field evolution. She is now a postdoctoral researcher at LMU in Munich, Germany. The third model, developed by graduate student Elisa Biagioli from the University of Pisa, uses advanced numerical techniques such as an implicit-explicit solver, to capture the field-scale evolution of lava flows. 

In 2018, shortly after the project began, a major effusive eruption occurred at Kīlauea volcano in Hawai'i. Our team quickly set out for the eruption, and helped capture aerial videos and images with drones that supported both civil defense and research efforts. Similar efforts were made during major eruptions in Iceland and the Canary Islands in 2021, leading to enhanced collaboration between our team and the local monitoring agencies. These field activities also provided valuable data for our numerical models and laboratory experiments. Postdoctoral researchers Dr. Julie Oppenheimer and Dr. Brett Carr participated in the response efforts in Hawai’i and graduate student Janine Birnbaum participated in the response in Iceland and Spain. 7 undergraduate students used the data in research projects. 

Dr. Carr continued the field-based research using aerial photography to document the evolution of lava flows and domes in Sinabung and Merapi volcanoes in Indonesia. Our work on these eruptions, which we combined with numerical models of dome stability, revealed the importance of passive collapses which develop between magma extrusion periods and are driven by weakening and interaction with confining topography. After LDEO, Dr. Carr went to work at the USGS and the University of Arizona. 

Broader Impacts Outcomes:

As a CAREER grant, this project included significant educational and outreach efforts. Students and educators were involved in analog experiments and numerical modeling, while field activities provided engaging content for public outreach. For example, a physics high-school teacher, Christopher Griffiths, spent two weeks in our lab developing lesson plans on viscosity and fluid dynamics, later shared with educators during an “Earth2Class” professional development session.

Our work on lava flows and our experiences at the Kīlauea and Cumbre Vieja eruptions inspired a demonstration used at various outreach events. This activity includes pouring wax "lava" onto a model town. The presenter, often a student, engages the audience in discussions about forecasting, hazard mitigation, and magma properties. Thermal cameras, a common eruption monitoring tool, were an attractive component of the demonstrations. We also showcased our aerial and ground-based videos of the recent eruptions in a unique immersive experience accompanied by educational narration, developed by film professional Patrick Brooks. 

Our experience during the 2021 eruption in Iceland led to a collaboration with journalist Heidi Julavits, resulting in an article for the New Yorker. PI Lev also wrote opinion columns for CNN about the 2018 and 2021 eruptions.

The project supported the training of future volcanologists, involving 3 postdoctoral researchers, 3 graduate students, 7 undergraduates, and 6 high-school students. PI Lev mentored at the 2019 CIDER summer school and organized workshops on UAS use in volcanology and numerical modeling of magmatic processes during the 2017 IAVCEI convention.
